TailParas.Para: Wang Leehom
Linfair Records
3 stars
Taiwanese-American singer-songwriter Wang Leehom has two daughters - one born in July 2014, the other in October 2016.
And there are signs of doting fatherhood all over his 16th album.

Most obviously, it is on Dearest, a track dedicated to them both. One can imagine him singing this lullaby at night, trying to coax his girls into slumberland: "I can pat your back until your breath is even/Quietly whisper in your ear I love you/ Wish for a flying elephant to appear in your dreams tonight/Leave talk of future dreams for later".
It is on the laidback track, World Without Tears, which works in an appearance by the erhu, that he dreams of "living in a world without tears, who is this happiness for".
The answer seems to be pretty clear for Wang.
When he sings "Oh baby baby baby baby don't act cute" on Thousands Of Generations, he could well be referring to actual babies.
Even the synth-pop title track, about the impact of artificial intelligence on people's lives, seems to stem from concern for his children's well-being.
Too bad it sounds clunky and unwieldy, from the juxtaposition of A.I. with Ai, the Chinese word for "love", to the awkward refrain of "Where should ethics be placed?"
Maybe not in this song.
Boon Chan
JAZZ
ELLA AT ZARDI'S
Ella Fitzgerald
Verve
5 stars

At what point, you have to wonder, will jazz labels stop unearthing unreleased records from their vaults. Given the penchant for madly reissuing every second-rate track stuffed to the back of the shelves, I was initially leery of this album.

What convinced me was the fact that this particular live recording was originally intended by producer Norman Grantz as the shiny debut of jazz legend Ella Fitzgerald for his then-newly minted Verve label. Also, the album is on sale on the iTunes store, priced at US$7.99 (S$10.50) instead of the usual US$9.99, which makes these 21 tracks an irresistible bargain.

Recorded over two evenings at Hollywood's Zardi's Jazzland in 1956, Fitzgerald, then aged 39, is at her impish, melodic best here. It is hard to believe she was once seized by stage fright, when you listen to her hold a rapt audience captive in this recording.

She banters lightly, jokingly warning the audience that she has forgotten one line for Tenderly and graciously acceding to called-out song requests. But it is her silky, swingy deliveries of standards such as It All Depends On You, S'Wonderful and I've Got A Crush On You that hint at the greatness to come in the classic series of albums that she would record for Verve, which set the gold standard for the Great American Songbook.

She croons Cry Me A River for a crowdpleasing velvety effect, tucking in a quote from I Cried For You, for good measure. She would go on to refine the former to more heartbreaking effect, but the technical polish is effortless here.

The showstopping scat number Airmail Special is here too, but the standout track is In A Mellow Tone. It is breathtaking how seamlessly she segues from straight delivery, to improvised scat, to a modified quote from The Song Has Ended.
Even when she confesses she cannot remember the lyrics to Gone With The Wind, she manages a swoonsome delivery of the standard before entertaining the audience with a humorous improvised ending.
The greatest marvel is why this has languished, unreleased, in Verve's vault for more than 60 years. It is the stuff of legends.
Ong Sor Fern
CLASSICAL
FRANCK, FAURE, PROKOFIEV: FLUTE SONATAS
Sharon Bezaly, Flute
Vladimir Ashkenazy, Piano
BIS 2259
5 stars

The surnames of flautist Sharon Bezaly and pianist Vladimir Ashkenazy are printed in a large gold font, sitting on top of composers Cesar Franck, Gabriel Faure and Sergei Prokofiev, as if relegating them to secondary importance. Such is the cult of big-name performers, supposedly to enhance the desirability of recordings, not that it matters much in this case.

Flautists have always appropriated the wider repertoire of violinists and this album displays two famous examples. Both Cesar Franck's Violin Sonata In A Major (in Jean-Pierre Rampal's adaptation) and Gabriel Faure's Violin Sonata No. 1 (arranged by Bezaly) translate very well for the flute, which occupies mostly the same register as the violin.
Given Bezaly's nimbleness and virtuosity, these exemplary performances do much to further that proposition.

Operating in the reverse direction, Prokofiev's Flute Sonata was later published as his Violin Sonata No. 2. Although less often heard than its violin guise, the original work is beloved of flautists. One of the most lyrical Russian scores, Bezaly makes most of its bittersweet musings.

Ashkenazy, who no longer gives public piano performances, is the ideal partner in all three works, where the piano plays an extraordinarily demanding role. The recording is in the demonstration class and makes for pleasurable listening.
Chang Tou Liang
